HOPKINS PHYSICIST
GAINS NEW HONOR

A Fantastic Tragedy

Dr. Robert W. Wood, professor
of experimental physics at the Hopkins, was recently awarded an honorary membership in the London
Physical Society, according to an
announcement from the President's
office.
Regarded as one of the most outstanding experimental physicists in
the world, Dr. Wood has been the
recipient of several awards for his
work in optics. Recently he was
awarded the "Ives Medal for Distinguished Work in Optics."

"It Is Night" is described as a
"fantastic tragedy". The scene is
laid in a barren desert, and as the
curtain rises, two soldiers of fortune are seen seated about a fire.
One is immersed in deep contemplation; the other is busy eating.
Suddenly "The Woman" appears.
For "The Contemplative Man", the
great quest is over, but "The Fleshly One" has other ideas. Just what
those "other ideas" are makes the
plot of "It Is Night" a colorful and
absorbing one.
The program of November 6 is
the first in a series of five lectures
and plays which appear on this
year's Playshop program. In addition, there are to be three major
bills, the first of which consists of
three one-act plays written by
members of the Hopkins faculty.
They will be presented the week of
November 20. Scheduled for later
in the season are "Hedda Gabler",
by Hendrik Ibsen, and an original
full-length play by an American
playwright.
Season tickets for admittance to
all plays and lectures at a price of
$2.00 are now on sale at the desk in
the reading room. Single admissions are 25 cents for lectures and
75 cents for plays.

Price, 5 Cents

Dr. G. Opdyke, Assembly Speaker
is Veritable Soldier Of Fortune
At Present an Amateur Art Critic, He Has Engaged in Engineering, Mining, Law, Prospecting and
Business During Career •
Dr. George Howard Opdyke, well
known as an amateur art critic, will
speak at the assembly on Thursday.
The subject of his lecture will be
"Art Appreciation".
Dr. Opdyke evoked considerable
attention when he published his book
Art and Nature Appreciation. Because of its new, refreshing approach to its subject, and comprehensive thoroughness, this volume
has called forth praise and commendation from critics, artists, writers, and teachers, all over the
United States.
John L. Wheeler, librarian of the
Enoch Pratt Free Library of Baltimore, commenting on the book,
said,"I predict that it will be one of
the stand-bys in art literature for
many years to come." The Carnegie
Corporations purchased copies of
the $3.50 book for distribution.

Would Lighten Burden,
Provide Better Engineering Education
Realizing that the present fouryear engineering course does not
include enough cultural subjects, a
plan has been launched under the
sponsorship of Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity, whereby it is proposed to
lengthen the course and insert more
subjects into the technical curriculum.
In accordance with this proposal,
a meeting was held in Levering Hall
on Friday night. Attended by the
members of the Hopkins chapter of
the honorary fraternity and several
of the outstanding students in the
engineering school, the meeting is to
be the first of a series in which this
plan will be discussed.

Advisers Before FulfillHeavy Hydrogen

"Theoretical and Experimental Research Problems Involving Heavy
Hydrogen" is the title of the first
Dohme lecture to be delivered by
Dr. Hugh S. Taylor, professor of
chemistry at Princeton University,
on November 17.
The lecture will review the theoretical problems arising from the
demonstrating of the separation of
hydrogen esotopes by electrolysis.
Details will be given of the plant
used at Princeton for the separation
and of its efficiency.

Plan Announced

The plan, as advanced at the
meeting, declares that the lengthier
course would lighten the burden of
the present course, enable the engineers to take more cultural courses
and enable the students to take part
in extra-curricular activities. Psychology, history, geology, and report
writing are some of the subjects
which were proposed to be instituted under this system.
Another proposal advanced is that
the first three years be devoted to a
general basic course in engineering,
while the last two years would be
devoted to specialized work. Under
this system, it would furnish the
student a chance to be able to determine in which branch of engineering he would enter.

Tuesday, October 31, 1933

Sirs, A Word With You!
The President's report announces a decline of
over a quarter of a million in the income of the
University for 1932-33, as compared with the previous
fiscal year, and states that it is a matter of "deep
concern" to the administration. With a drop of 500
in enrolment already indicated for the year 1933-34
there's not a whole lot of hope for the President's
peace of mind.
Scarce indeed is the fiscal statement which does
not show tremendous shrinkages today. Being "off"
only one per cent of the approximate total assets of
the University constitutes, in fact, much less of a
grievance than the average financial embarrassment
to be found almost anywhere. But with the amount
of energy and thoughtfulness, labor and manipulation
which President Ames has expended in an effort to
keep our heads above water, we are wondering just
what would have been the degree of loss if things
had been let alone.
But the shortage has another aspect which is
decidedly more than of casual interest to "cash customers" of the Hopkins. If the money cannot be
gotten anywhere else; if the investment of endowment funds yields no more than it has, it is J. Finking
Puntworthy, III, undergraduate, who will have to
pay the price. The authorities have so little respect
for,tuition fees right now that they are constantly telling us that what we pay does not by any means cover
the actual cost of educating us. Deduce for yourself,
then, the logical one to be further assessed, assuming
that you see things from the administration's point
of view.
Our present fees are certainly not exorbitant,
considering the nature of the opportunities offered.
Hard to pay, yes. But so are all bills. It may be
even conceded that we have a right to pay more, but
that question is moot. However, there is one consideration which we would like to place before President Ames in this connection, namely, why not shift
a little of the burden onto the shoulders of the
graduate students?
Certainly if any part of the Homewood establishment receives more attention and pampering than
another, it is the graduate department. It has occupied a favored place in the affections of Hopkins
presidents for years past, and its interests have continually been allowed precedence over those of the
College and Economics and Engineering Schools. If
this attitude is justified by the greater value to the
University of the graduates and if graduates consider
it a provilege to study at the Hopkins because of the
better facilities provided, then ti is only logical that
their tuition should be made proportionate.
Under the present arrangement considerably
more than half of the enrollment is in the graduate

departments, yet the tuition for graduates is $50 less
less than for undergraduates. We don't want the
administration to soak those who boast higher intellectual attainment than we, but we would like to see
a little more equality in the financial burden placed
upon them. Either that, or accord us a greater share
of the benefits arising from the spending of Univer- Physical Examination Shows Reason for His Strange Power
sity funds.

Campus Big Shot Makes Slip
Reveals Secret Of Success

Who's A Liberal?
In past years a great deal of the good which
the Liberal Club has accomplished in its field has
been discounted in the eyes of the undergraduates on
account of the prominent part which several radical
graduate students have played in the carrying out of
the program. No matter how unwelcome the fact
may be to the Liberal Club membership, it must be
realized that before the conservative and hesitant undergrad can be made radical, if that, indeed, be the
object of the Club, he must first be gently persuaded
to develop first an intellectual curiosity, next, a cautious liberalism, and lastly, a zealous radicalism.
It has impressed us as poor strategy to have allowed the Club to fall prey to the rosy-hued zealots
who have heretofore been the sole evidence to the
campus that a Liberal Club existed. It is such poor
psychology, don't y'know. To the terrified, and, often,
disdainful undergraduate mind the best possible illustration of a Liberalite was a wild-eyed, long-haired,
black-hatted individual who was ready to point his
finger at you any moment and intone in sinister manner something of this sort: "The blood of the murdered millions of Russia calls to you for revenge!"
Little wonder that the Club didn't cut such a fancy
figure in campus respect.
This fact has apparently been grasped by Richard
Feise, new Dresident of the group. When he addressed the first meeting of the year last Friday he
urged a more active part upon the undergraduates
present, who constituted practically the entire attendance. If the membership as well can be brought
to a realization of this and if the same calibre of
speaker as has come in the past continues, the prospect for achieving a worthwhile influence is considerably enhanced. A university such as the Johns Hopkins cannot afford to be without such an influence
among the students, and we look forward to an intelligent fulfillment by the Club of our expectations.

Intercollegiate News
A certain freshman football star at the University of Oklahoma worried about breaking his threeyear record for regular Sunday school attendance
when he was confined to his room following a tonsil
operation. As a result his Sunday school class held
its meeting in his infirmary -room.
Professor F. C. Baxter of the University of
Southern California claims that "The trouble with
collegiate humor publications is that they're not collegiate and they are seldom humorous."

Over Supporters;.0ther Data on
Students Given

Freshmen have looked at him
adulation beaming on their countenances. Sophomores hopefully
seek the blessing of his favor and
support in their political ambitions.
Juniors assiduously pattern their
methods after those of this wonderman. Seniors alone remain inscrutable. Ah, yes. Many have asked
what is that strange power which
Ted Stern has over faculty and
student-body.
Now don't think that there's any
joke about all this. No, sir! It
positively isn't funny—the way in
which he has wrapped them all
around his little finger. He's done
such a complete job of it that everybody has been absolutely baled; that
is, all except the seniors, of course.
When the news came out last week
as to how he did it, only these august personages nodded wisely, as
if they had known it all the time.
They would have probably nodded
wisely in any case, though. It's
what is expected of them.
Makes Fatal Slip

Even the greatest of men slip
sometimes, you know. He just
shouldn't have permitted himself to
take that strength test. But sure
enough, his chickens have come
to ropst—we now know that he has
a stronger grip than the next six
strongest men in the University!
Ordinarily, we wouldn't have permitted ourselves to speak upon such
a matter, but after all, we do owe
something to our devoted readers.
It's needless to point out how a
man gets a grip like that. The results show that when he bears down,
enough energy is expended to push
all the men in Levering Hall clear

had enough money to live on while
he combined material representing
years of work into book form.
Art was of great interest to him,
but one day when he visited the Metropolitan Museum in New York, it
became a passion. An artist friend
explained how to recognize and appreciate good art. Thereafter his
spare time was always devoted to
furthering this knowledge.
Writes Book Himself

However, in all his research in
libraries he never found a book
which could explain comprehensively the fundamental laws and
principles of art.
"Why don't you write it yourself ?" a museum director asked him.
So write it he did, and Art and Nature Appreciation was the result.
For eight months Dr. Opdyke
wrote steadily. Then his house and
manuscript were demolished by a
fire. But he started all over again,
and in a year and a half exhibited
the finished product. It aroused
enthusiasm in many quarters, and
has been labeled one of the best
books in its field.

The Frosh Surprise us
Although this was by far the
most interesting fact gleaned from
the figures which are known to us
to date concerning the results of the
physical examinations, yet there are
some remarkable things which our
extensive reader-service requires
that we publish. The height of the
average student has increased to
such an extent that if all of the
freshmen alone were laid end to end
on Charles Street they'd tie up traffic for blocks. But this revelation
pales before the discovery that the
combined weight of these men is so
great that if it were put on wheels
and given a slight push it would roll
all the way to Goucher College.
Taking five-eighths of the composite strength of the sophomore
class it is estimated that seventythree tables in Joe's bar could be
overturned at once. The remaining
three-eighths is equal to the task of
dragging ninety-eight per cent of
the freshmen to open-house parties.

THE EMERSON HOTEL

Scoring its first victory of the
season last Saturday, the Johns
Hopkins cross-country team defeated the Haverford College harriers by a 40-19 score.
The Blue Jay runners led their
opponents throughout the entire
course of four and one-half miles.
King and Holtzman, who have been
consistent winners for Hopkins, tied
for first place in this meet, crossing
the finish line in the good time of
21 minutes and 26 seconds.
Jay Vees Meet Poly

Captain Roger Lewis and Sholtes
of the Black and Blue finished in a
tie for third and fourth places.
This Tuesday the Blue Jay Junior Varsity team will stage its first
meet of the season against Polytechnic Institute at Homewood.

HOPKINS PHYSICIST
GAINS NEW HONOR

A Fantastic Tragedy

Dr. Robert W. Wood, professor
of experimental physics at the Hopkins, was recently awarded an honorary membership in the London
Physical Society, according to an
announcement from the President's
office.
Regarded as one of the most outstanding experimental physicists in
the world, Dr. Wood has been the
recipient of several awards for his
work in optics. Recently he was
awarded the "Ives Medal for Distinguished Work in Optics."

"It Is Night" is described as a
"fantastic tragedy". The scene is
laid in a barren desert, and as the
curtain rises, two soldiers of fortune are seen seated about a fire.
One is immersed in deep contemplation; the other is busy eating.
Suddenly "The Woman" appears.
For "The Contemplative Man", the
great quest is over, but "The Fleshly One" has other ideas. Just what
those "other ideas" are makes the
plot of "It Is Night" a colorful and
absorbing one.
The program of November 6 is
the first in a series of five lectures
and plays which appear on this
year's Playshop program. In addition, there are to be three major
bills, the first of which consists of
three one-act plays written by
members of the Hopkins faculty.
They will be presented the week of
November 20. Scheduled for later
in the season are "Hedda Gabler",
by Hendrik Ibsen, and an original
full-length play by an American
playwright.
Season tickets for admittance to
all plays and lectures at a price of
$2.00 are now on sale at the desk in
the reading room. Single admissions are 25 cents for lectures and
75 cents for plays.

Dr. G. Opdyke, Assembly Speaker
is Veritable Soldier Of Fortune
At Present an Amateur Art Critic, He Has Engaged in Engineering, Mining, Law, Prospecting and
Business During Career •
Dr. George Howard Opdyke, well
known as an amateur art critic, will
speak at the assembly on Thursday.
The subject of his lecture will be
"Art Appreciation".
Dr. Opdyke evoked considerable
attention when he published his book
Art and Nature Appreciation. Because of its new, refreshing approach to its subject, and comprehensive thoroughness, this volume
has called forth praise and commendation from critics, artists, writers, and teachers, all over the
United States.
John L. Wheeler, librarian of the
Enoch Pratt Free Library of Baltimore, commenting on the book,
said,"I predict that it will be one of
the stand-bys in art literature for
many years to come." The Carnegie
Corporations purchased copies of
the $3.50 book for distribution.

Would Lighten Burden,
Provide Better Engineering Education
Realizing that the present fouryear engineering course does not
include enough cultural subjects, a
plan has been launched under the
sponsorship of Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity, whereby it is proposed to
lengthen the course and insert more
subjects into the technical curriculum.
In accordance with this proposal,
a meeting was held in Levering Hall
on Friday night. Attended by the
members of the Hopkins chapter of
the honorary fraternity and several
of the outstanding students in the
engineering school, the meeting is to
be the first of a series in which this
plan will be discussed.

"Theoretical and Experimental Research Problems Involving Heavy
Hydrogen" is the title of the first
Dohme lecture to be delivered by

chemistry at Princeton University,
on November 17.

the first three years be devoted to a
general basic course in engineering,
while the last two years would be
devoted to specialized work. Under
this system, it would furnish the
student a chance to be able to determine in which branch of engineering he would enter.

Tuesday, October 31, 1933

Sirs, A Word With You!
The President's report announces a decline of
over a quarter of a million in the income of the
University for 1932-33, as compared with the previous
fiscal year, and states that it is a matter of "deep
concern" to the administration. With a drop of 500
in enrolment already indicated for the year 1933-34
there's not a whole lot of hope for the President's
peace of mind.
Scarce indeed is the fiscal statement which does
not show tremendous shrinkages today. Being "off"
only one per cent of the approximate total assets of
the University constitutes, in fact, much less of a
grievance than the average financial embarrassment
to be found almost anywhere. But with the amount
of energy and thoughtfulness, labor and manipulation
which President Ames has expended in an effort to
keep our heads above water, we are wondering just
what would have been the degree of loss if things
had been let alone.
But the shortage has another aspect which is
decidedly more than of casual interest to "cash customers" of the Hopkins. If the money cannot be
gotten anywhere else; if the investment of endowment funds yields no more than it has, it is J. Finking
Puntworthy, III, undergraduate, who will have to
pay the price. The authorities have so little respect
for,tuition fees right now that they are constantly telling us that what we pay does not by any means cover
the actual cost of educating us. Deduce for yourself,
then, the logical one to be further assessed, assuming
that you see things from the administration's point
of view.
Our present fees are certainly not exorbitant,
considering the nature of the opportunities offered.
Hard to pay, yes. But so are all bills. It may be
even conceded that we have a right to pay more, but
that question is moot. However, there is one consideration which we would like to place before President Ames in this connection, namely, why not shift
a little of the burden onto the shoulders of the
graduate students?
Certainly if any part of the Homewood establishment receives more attention and pampering than
another, it is the graduate department. It has occupied a favored place in the affections of Hopkins
presidents for years past, and its interests have continually been allowed precedence over those of the
College and Economics and Engineering Schools. If
this attitude is justified by the greater value to the
University of the graduates and if graduates consider
it a provilege to study at the Hopkins because of the
better facilities provided, then ti is only logical that
their tuition should be made proportionate.
Under the present arrangement considerably
more than half of the enrollment is in the graduate

departments, yet the tuition for graduates is $50 less
less than for undergraduates. We don't want the
administration to soak those who boast higher intellectual attainment than we, but we would like to see
a little more equality in the financial burden placed
upon them. Either that, or accord us a greater share
of the benefits arising from the spending of Univer- Physical Examination Shows Reason for His Strange Power
sity funds.

Campus Big Shot Makes Slip
Reveals Secret Of Success

Who's A Liberal?
In past years a great deal of the good which
the Liberal Club has accomplished in its field has
been discounted in the eyes of the undergraduates on
account of the prominent part which several radical
graduate students have played in the carrying out of
the program. No matter how unwelcome the fact
may be to the Liberal Club membership, it must be
realized that before the conservative and hesitant undergrad can be made radical, if that, indeed, be the
object of the Club, he must first be gently persuaded
to develop first an intellectual curiosity, next, a cautious liberalism, and lastly, a zealous radicalism.
It has impressed us as poor strategy to have allowed the Club to fall prey to the rosy-hued zealots
who have heretofore been the sole evidence to the
campus that a Liberal Club existed. It is such poor
psychology, don't y'know. To the terrified, and, often,
disdainful undergraduate mind the best possible illustration of a Liberalite was a wild-eyed, long-haired,
black-hatted individual who was ready to point his
finger at you any moment and intone in sinister manner something of this sort: "The blood of the murdered millions of Russia calls to you for revenge!"
Little wonder that the Club didn't cut such a fancy
figure in campus respect.
This fact has apparently been grasped by Richard
Feise, new Dresident of the group. When he addressed the first meeting of the year last Friday he
urged a more active part upon the undergraduates
present, who constituted practically the entire attendance. If the membership as well can be brought
to a realization of this and if the same calibre of
speaker as has come in the past continues, the prospect for achieving a worthwhile influence is considerably enhanced. A university such as the Johns Hopkins cannot afford to be without such an influence
among the students, and we look forward to an intelligent fulfillment by the Club of our expectations.

Art was of great interest to him,
but one day when he visited the Metropolitan Museum in New York, it
became a passion. An artist friend
explained how to recognize and appreciate good art. Thereafter his
spare time was always devoted to
furthering this knowledge.
Writes Book Himself

However, in all his research in
libraries he never found a book
which could explain comprehensively the fundamental laws and
principles of art.
"Why don't you write it yourself ?" a museum director asked him.
So write it he did, and Art and Nature Appreciation was the result.
For eight months Dr. Opdyke
wrote steadily. Then his house and
manuscript were demolished by a
fire. But he started all over again,
and in a year and a half exhibited
the finished product. It aroused
enthusiasm in many quarters, and
has been labeled one of the best
books in its field.

The Frosh Surprise us
Although this was by far the
most interesting fact gleaned from
the figures which are known to us
to date concerning the results of the
physical examinations, yet there are
some remarkable things which our
extensive reader-service requires
that we publish. The height of the
average student has increased to
such an extent that if all of the
freshmen alone were laid end to end
on Charles Street they'd tie up traffic for blocks. But this revelation
pales before the discovery that the
combined weight of these men is so
great that if it were put on wheels
and given a slight push it would roll
all the way to Goucher College.
Taking five-eighths of the composite strength of the sophomore
class it is estimated that seventythree tables in Joe's bar could be
overturned at once. The remaining
three-eighths is equal to the task of
dragging ninety-eight per cent of
the freshmen to open-house parties.

THE EMERSON HOTEL

Scoring its first victory of the
season last Saturday, the Johns
Hopkins cross-country team defeated the Haverford College harriers by a 40-19 score.
The Blue Jay runners led their
opponents throughout the entire
course of four and one-half miles.
King and Holtzman, who have been
consistent winners for Hopkins, tied
for first place in this meet, crossing
the finish line in the good time of
21 minutes and 26 seconds.
Jay Vees Meet Poly

Captain Roger Lewis and Sholtes
of the Black and Blue finished in a
tie for third and fourth places.
This Tuesday the Blue Jay Junior Varsity team will stage its first
meet of the season against Polytechnic Institute at Homewood.

Engineering School, will serve as
adviser. The expressed purpose of
the organization is to promote and
maintain interest in radio.
Students who wish to learn more
about the club are requested to get
in touch with Charles Hastings,
